title: Composite heater hardware, electronics, software and controller
overview: The goal was to rebuild the composite heater, reusing only the main structural parts salvaged from the old furnace after the building was demolished one year earlier.
The project involved purchasing thermal insulation boards and reconstructing the heater.
As the electrical team coordinator, I was responsible for designing the electrical and control system, including selecting protections (overcurrent, residual current, door safety switches).
The goal also included designing measurement circuits using NTC thermistors and control circuits with microcontroller GPIO pins controlling transistors, which in turn control SSRs.
Part of the task was implementing and designing a regulator and a parametric setpoint generator to allow the composite team to set target temperature, heating/cooling rate, and process duration.
This project was done within the Student Research Group AGH Solar Boat, where I served as the coordinator for electrical and electronics team at the time.
highlights: Coordinated the team on selecting protections and assembling the control cabinet.
Designed and built the control PCB with buttons and a display as the user interface.
Developed the entire firmware in Arduino C to speed up development.
Implemented and manually tuned a PI controller.
results: The furnace enabled manufacturing key boat parts such as pylons, hydrofoils, photovoltaic panels, and many others.
The furnace has been operating reliably since its completion in January 2023.
Future work could include creating a MATLAB model of the furnace and optimizing the controller design.
Additionally, migrating from Arduino to a more capable microcontroller such as ESP or Raspberry Pi would be beneficial.
